awd_titl_txt: Planning: CRISES: Climate Inequality and Integrative Resilience Center
awd_abstract_narration:
Inequality undermines communities' climate resilience - or their ability to adapt, self-organize, and transform in response to climate change-related disruptions. At the same time, climate change will magnify existing inequalities. The vicious cycle between climate change and inequality has multiple interacting causes and consequences that call for rigorous interdisciplinary research. This planning project will bring together researchers, community members, and practitioners to envision and build the Climate Inequality and Integrative Resilience (CLIIR) Center. The CLIIR Center will aim to advance scientific knowledge on the links between inequality and climate resilience to inform climate resilience policy decisions.  
 
To establish the CLIIR Center as an impactful center of excellence, we will carry out planning activities informed by convergence (a.k.a. transdisciplinary) research principles and practices. The planning activities will bring together academic and community collaborators for dialogues and structured activities. These activities will: 1) expand and deepen external partnerships; 2) build capacity for collaborative and transdisciplinary research; 3) clarify the new Center's thematic areas; and 4) develop resources and frameworks to establish the CLIIR Center as a hub for climate resilience decision support. The activities will include community conversations, theoretical / methodological dialogues prompted by research presentations, collaborative research skills training, climate justice workshops, and the collection of case studies in metro-Boston on the use of decision-support tools in climate resilience projects. With climate resilience and inequality as an umbrella, we will primarily explore three research themes: Indigenous Knowledge and Governance, Climate Migration, and Climate Change and Health. These themes will serve as test cases for future studies on models of, interactions among, and impacts in different resilience domains and their intersections with inequality. The planning activities will yield research questions and hypotheses on the mechanisms through which climate change impacts lead to disparate quality-of-life outcomes in communities.  

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Establishing the CLIIR Center

On October 1, 2023, the Sustainable Solutions Lab (SSL) at the University of Massachusetts Boston received a $100,000 NSF CRISES planning grant to establish the Climate Inequality and Integrative Resilience Center (CLIIR Center). This center aims to advance knowledge on how climate change impacts lead to disparities in quality-of-life outcomes. Its integrative approach emphasizes two key dimensions: converging a range of disciplinary perspectives to understand the intersection of inequality and climate change and fostering holistic understandings of resilience, including social, ecological, and infrastructural. The ultimate goal is to inform policies, practices, and structures that enhance communities’ resilience to climate change.

The CLIIR Center’s research agenda focuses on 1) developing resilience models, 2) understanding interactions among inequality, ecological, infrastructural, and social resilience, and 3) maximizing societal well-being through climate resilience initiatives.

The CLIIR Center builds on the SSL’s nearly 10-year history of promoting equitable climate adaptation in metro-Boston communities. SSL is a cross-disciplinary institute partnering with six schools and four institutes at UMass Boston, including the School for the Environment and the McCormack Graduate School of Policy and Global Studies. Its focus has been on faculty support, community collaboration, and addressing climate-related challenges through innovative research and action.

Planning Activities for CLIIR Center Development

The grant facilitated planning activities that engaged academic and community collaborators across metro-Boston, Massachusetts, and the northeast region. The objectives included:

1. Expanding and deepening partnerships.

2. Building capacity for transdisciplinary research.

3. Clarifying research themes and questions.

4. Developing resources to establish the CLIIR Center as a decision-support hub.

Expanding and Deepening External Partnerships

The planning process fostered meaningful collaboration among UMass Boston faculty and external stakeholders. Faculty from diverse disciplines engaged in transdisciplinary dialogues on climate resilience, governance, and adaptation. This broadened understanding enabled SSL to develop strong partnerships grounded in mutual respect and shared goals.

Key collaborators included the Lumbee (North Carolin) and Nipmuc (Massachusetts) tribal nations, Professionals of Color in the Environment (POCIE), Environmental Center for Climate Change Communications, Conservation, Health & Ocean research (ECHO), the Toolbox Dialogue Initiative (TDI), Massachusetts Ecosystem Climate Adaptation Network (Mass ECAN), Consult LeLa, and the Mattapan Food and Fitness Coalition (MFFC). Through conversations with tribal nations and residents of Mattapan and Dorchester, researchers gained insights into potential areas of research tied to the needs and agendas of different community stakeholders.

Building Capacity for Collaborative Research

Internally, the Climate Justice Deep Dive—a 20–25-hour intensive program—enhanced research capacity among UMass Boston faculty and staff. Bi-weekly sessions fostered collaborative learning on climate justice and resilience, connecting academic efforts to community initiatives. Participants acquired skills for transdisciplinary research, promoting a deeper understanding of climate challenges. A notable outcome was a graduate student network publication. We piloted a collaborative writing project with UMass Boston graduate students interested in the connections between inequality and climate change. The resulting publication, “Community-Led Climate Preparedness and Resilience in the Boston Area: New Evidence from Communities of Color,” was published in the Climate open-access journal. The piece highlighted the need for community-driven solutions and amplified the perspectives of Asian, Black, Latino, and Native American Bostonians. 

Enhancing Team Collaboration and Clarifying Research Focus

The planning process strengthened collaborative execution among researchers, resulting in thematic workshops and regular meetings. Workshops on Climate Migration, Indigenous Knowledge, Climate Change and Health, and Governance featured scholars, Indigenous leaders, and local experts. These events bridged theoretical inquiry with practitioner insights, leading to co-authored journal articles and white papers. The Climate Migration workshop explored the complex drivers of displacement, explore legal and policy frameworks to advance well-being in the context of displacement, and highlighted the importance of integration across the social sciences and humanities. The Indigenous Knowledge workshop emphasized traditional ecological knowledge's integration into policy, while the Climate Change and Health workshop focused on the intersection of public health and environmental justice. Insights from these workshops guided the development of research products, including a commentary on climate migration under review by the Local Environment journal.

Developing Decision Support Resources

The planning phase launched a Decision Science Support Hub (DSH) team composed of scholars specializing in agent-based modeling, systems dynamics, community-driven decision science, and artificial intelligence. This team engaged in a research convergence process over the course of the year, through collaboration on a position paper that outlines the ways that decision support tools, like agent-based modeling, can advance climate justice and integrate qualitative and other data from community participation. The DSH team is completing a position paper for submission to Nature Sustainability.

Conclusion

The CLIIR Center’s planning phase has strengthened SSL’s research capacity, expanded partnerships, refined research directions, and developed decision support tools. These accomplishments position the CLIIR Center as a leader in climate resilience research and community-centered solutions to address inequality, paving the way for sustained impact in the evolving field of climate justice.
